Hi Bryan,

>I'm currently working on a modification to NEAT (using a genetic
>regulatory network to create a more flexible genome), and I had a
>question about parameter settings.
>
>  
>
This sounds very interesting, do you have any more details worked out 
yet? Also, I was wondering (since you're at MIT) if you were working 
with Dr. O'Reilly?

>My question, then, is this: how do you set the parameters that govern
>the NEAT system?  I've played with mutation rates (especially
>structural), speciation settings (including dynamic thresholding), and
>the other odds and ends (popsize, minimum size for elitism, fraction
>of parents to reproduce, weight caps), but I'm not always sure what
>I'm looking for when I make changes.  What, aside from a solution, are
>the variables to look for when evaluating the quality of a run?
>  
>
Unfortunately the only advice I have is to tweak the parameters as 
systematically as possible and record all the results :) As Derek 
pointed out there is the possibility of tweaking the parameters during 
the course of evolution (similar to what is done in evolution 
strategies), and every now and then someone proposes to build a 
meta-genetic algorithm, but to answer your question, no I don't think 
there is really anything worthwhile outside of being as systematic as 
possible with ad-hoc tweaking. I would contend though that tweaking is 
much less important than building a good algorithm. As long as your 
parameters are sane (large enough population, low enough mutation rate, 
good dynamic thresholding, etc), evolution generally can sort out the 
rest for itself. Basically, in tweaking an evolutionary system, unlike 
in tweaking an engineered system, the changes often just get lost in the 
noise of the algorithm.

To answer your second question, we generally look at algorithm 
efficiency and solution quality. The efficiency can be measured as just 
how many generations it takes to get to a certain benchmark fitness. 
Some other things you might want to look at is the variance of the 
genotypes (to check how converged the population has become), the 
"shape" of the fitness curve (e.g. if there are any spikes which may 
indicate topological breakthrough, or just stagnation, etc), and how the 
species' are divided (i.e. do one or more species dominate the 
population). These are all off the top of my head, but each one gives 
another clue as to what actually occured during evolution, and I think 
at least during the testing phase of your algorithm, its more important 
to look at these than just the final solution quality.

Good luck on your project.

Joe
